- File is malformed JSON -> null (expected)

- File is a directory -> null (UNEXPECTED)

title: QA: printSummary has logic bug in pass/skip count display

In cli/lib/output.ts:56 and :68, the conditional uses ?? (nullish coalescing) instead of || (logical OR):

  if (counts['pass'] ?? counts['created']) { ... }
  if (counts['skip'] ?? counts['skipped']) { ... }

This is wrong because:
- If counts['pass'] is 0 (falsy but not null/undefined), ?? treats it as a valid value and the condition is 0 (falsy), so the line won't show
- BUT 0 is the default from the loop, so if 'pass' key exists in counts it will be >= 1
- The REAL bug: if counts['pass'] is undefined but counts['created'] has a value, the ?? works correctly. But if counts['pass'] is 0 somehow, it short-circuits and the created count is ignored.

Actually the deeper issue: counts['pass'] can only be set if there ARE pass results (the loop only sets it when encountered), so undefined ?? counts['created'] works. But this is fragile and confusing. Should use || for clarity, or better yet just check both counts explicitly.

File: cli/lib/output.ts:56, 68
Severity: Low - works by accident but confusing code
close_reason: Fixed: printSummary uses arithmetic check instead of ?? falsy

title: QA: init does not set exit code on failure
description:
In cli/commands/init.ts, runInit() always prints 'Adjutant init complete.' and returns void without setting an exit code. Compare with doctor.ts which returns an exit code (0 or 1).

If init encounters failures (e.g., can't create directory due to permissions, can't write settings.json), it should:
1. Track whether any step failed
2. Return a non-zero exit code
3. Print a failure message instead of success

The bin/cli.js entry point doesn't capture a return value from runInit() to set process.exitCode. Only errors that throw will cause a non-zero exit.

This means a CI pipeline or script running 'adjutant init' would always see exit code 0 even if critical steps failed.

title: QA: getVersion() in cli/index.ts resolves wrong package.json path when compiled
description:
In cli/index.ts:24, getVersion() reads package.json relative to __dirname:

  readFileSync(join(__dirname, '..', 'package.json'), 'utf-8')

When compiled, __dirname is dist/cli/, so '..' resolves to dist/, not the project root. The package.json is at the project root, not in dist/. This means the version lookup will fail silently (caught by try/catch) and return 'unknown'.

title: QA: adjutantHookRegistered() checks wrong hook command vs what init will register

title: Refactor: getThreads correlated subquery is N+1-like
description: In message-store.ts getThreads(), the latest_body column uses a correlated subquery: (SELECT body FROM messages m2 WHERE m2.thread_id = messages.thread_id ORDER BY created_at DESC LIMIT 1). This executes once per group, making it O(threads * messages_per_thread). For a small dataset this is fine, but it won't scale. The query also has an ambiguity: when multiple agents post in a thread, the GROUP BY agent_id means you get one row per (thread_id, agent_id) pair, not one row per thread_id. The correlated subquery also doesn't filter by agent_id, so it returns the latest body from ANY agent in that thread, not necessarily the grouping agent. Fix: use a window function (ROW_NUMBER() OVER PARTITION BY thread_id ORDER BY created_at DESC) or restructure the query.

title: QA: commandAvailable() uses 'which' - not portable to all Linux distros
description:
In cli/lib/checks.ts:41, commandAvailable() uses 'which' to check if a command exists:

  execSync('which ${command}', { stdio: 'ignore' })

The 'which' command is not POSIX-standard and is not available on all Linux distributions (e.g., some minimal Debian/Alpine images). The POSIX-portable alternative is 'command -v'. This should be:

  execSync('command -v ${command}', { stdio: 'ignore' })

Note: 'command -v' requires a shell, but execSync uses /bin/sh by default so this works.
